comment.body: Any ideas @xvzcf? It runs on my mac when compiling with gcc; currently I'm not able to compile with clang. Are the AVX flags getting set for clang on macOS?

src/kem/frodokem/CMakeLists.txt
```
if(OQS_USE_AES_INSTRUCTIONS AND OQS_USE_AVX2_INSTRUCTIONS)
    target_compile_options(frodokem PRIVATE -maes -mavx2)
endif()
```
Tests are successful only on machines that support AVX2. I suppose you should remove this check for instructions.

issue.title: "Optimized" CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE should possibly be renamed to Release
issue.body:
The cmake profile `Optimized` to build with `-O2` etc, seems to break CMake convention. The Rust ``cmake`` crate has a [automatic profile selection](https://docs.rs/cmake/0.1.42/cmake/struct.Config.html#method.profile) that expects ``Release`` instead of ``Optimized``.

This seems to match https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/variable/CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE.html, which also suggests that #652 was abusing ``CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE`` a little bit...

comment.body: This is no longer up-to-date then? https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Customizing-liboqs#cmake_build_type

issue.title: Add AVX2 and AESNI versions of SPHINCS+
issue.body:
Also remove all of the dead code that was included (probably due to a name format change sometime).

Closes #721 

I'm not entirely sure how `copy_from_pqclean.py` works, so I could probably use some direction there. Specifically, the use of `sources` is unclear to me.

issue.title: "Optimized" CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE should possibly be renamed to Release
issue.body:
The cmake profile `Optimized` to build with `-O2` etc, seems to break CMake convention. The Rust ``cmake`` crate has a [automatic profile selection](https://docs.rs/cmake/0.1.42/cmake/struct.Config.html#method.profile) that expects ``Release`` instead of ``Optimized``.

This seems to match https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/variable/CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE.html, which also suggests that #652 was abusing ``CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE`` a little bit...

comment.body: Right, the statement is not quite accurate anymore: The catch-all `-mnative` has been replaced by CPU-specific optimisation flags at each target and those targets (aim to) test for run-time presence of those capabilities. Until this has been added to all algorithms, the statement that the resulting binary (built on a platform supporting all optimisation features like AVX2) may not be portable (i.e., crash on platforms without AVX2 in the same example) still is correct, though. Ultimately, that sentence should go, too, i.e., `Optimised` build binaries should run the fastest code possible on the platform it happens to run on.

issue.title: Adding separate AVX2 runtime-checked common/sha3
issue.body: In pursuit of #624 provide clean and RT-protected AVX2 optimised variant(s) of SHA3.

comment.body: A few of the files look like they are duplicated in both src/common and src/common\_avx2, such as sha3\_ossl.c and sha3\_c.c.  Is that true? (If so, why?) Or are there differences? (If so, then we should make a note about those differences so they can be preserved if the different versions of the files get updated.)

issue.title: Adding separate AVX2 runtime-checked common/sha3
issue.body: In pursuit of #624 provide clean and RT-protected AVX2 optimised variant(s) of SHA3.

comment.body: Indeed, `sha3_ossl.c` is an oversight and could be deleted (as for all I know it has no AVX2 dependency). `sha3_c.c` in the AVX2 case does carry a few stubs necessary/worth retaining (the redundant stuff I deleted). What is true, though, is that the core "functionality" files are exact copies and get different "functionality" only by #defines putting them into a different symbol namespace. I'm just not sure whether symlinks are possible across platforms (Windows?)

issue.title: "Optimized" CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE should possibly be renamed to Release
issue.body:
The cmake profile `Optimized` to build with `-O2` etc, seems to break CMake convention. The Rust ``cmake`` crate has a [automatic profile selection](https://docs.rs/cmake/0.1.42/cmake/struct.Config.html#method.profile) that expects ``Release`` instead of ``Optimized``.

This seems to match https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/variable/CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE.html, which also suggests that #652 was abusing ``CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE`` a little bit...

comment.body: I'll update the wiki once the changes are settled.

issue.title: Adding separate AVX2 runtime-checked common/sha3
issue.body: In pursuit of #624 provide clean and RT-protected AVX2 optimised variant(s) of SHA3.

comment.body: I'll take a look at this once the fix for https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/695 goes in.

issue.title: liboqs installation problem
issue.body:
Hi, I tried to install the liboqs but on `ninja run_tests` it fails on tests/test_style.py::test_style at 97%, after that i tried the command `ninja install` but it returns the following error: 
```

[0/1] Install the project...
-- Install configuration: ""
-- Installing: /usr/local/lib/liboqs.a
CMake Error at src/cmake_install.cmake:41 (file):
  file INSTALL cannot copy file "/home/pg41101/liboqs/build/lib/liboqs.a" to
  "/usr/local/lib/liboqs.a".
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  cmake_install.cmake:42 (include)


FAILED: CMakeFiles/install.util
cd /home/pg41101/liboqs/build && /usr/bin/cmake -P cmake_install.cmake
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
```

But running the same command with root it works: 

```
[0/1] Install the project...
-- Install configuration: ""
-- Installing: /usr/local/lib/liboqs.a
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/oqs.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/common.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/rand.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/aes.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sha2.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sha3.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_bike.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_frodokem.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_sike.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_picnic.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_qtesla.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_classic_mceliece.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_kyber.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_ledacrypt.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_newhope.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_ntru.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_saber.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_threebears.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_dilithium.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_falcon.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_mqdss.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_rainbow.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_sphincs.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/oqsconfig.h

```
Honestly I don't even know if is correctly installed but my main reason to install this library is to use it with the python3 wrappers **liboqs-python**, so after I clone the the project I ran the command `oqs/oqs.py` and it returns the following message `No liboqs shared libraries found`.

I have very poor experience on installing/compiling libraries, would appreciate if anyone could help me or guide me to install liboqs successfully so i can use **liboqs-python**.

Thank you.

comment.body: Closing for now. Please re-open or file a new issue if the problem persists.

issue.title: Windows Issues
issue.body:
On my Windows 10 Enterprise VM, with with Ninja build tool and MSVC compiler. Target platform as reported by `speed_sig`: AMD64-Windows-10.0.18363.

1) Using 32-bit `cl.exe`, the build fails with the following messages:

![sike_fail](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21228961/78150570-77b17b00-7405-11ea-944b-869260ec974c.png)

For 64-bit builds:

2) `Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic` keypair generation takes 71.156 seconds, as measured by `speed_sig`. Signing takes 35.61 seconds. It once increased the runtime of `ninja run_tests` by 10 minutes, but this seems to be non-deterministic.

3) The SPHINCS and Rainbow variants seem in general to impose a big slow down on `ninja run_tests`.

4) `kat_sig` with `Falcon-512` and `Falcon-1024` results in heap corruption errors.

comment.body: Shall we close this issue then?

issue.title: Reduce check-in testing on AppVeyor
issue.body:
As it might be so 
- that we cannot use CircleCI for Windows testing (see [PR #690](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/690)), and 
- the AppVeyor account is rather slow regarding Windows testing (@vsoftco and @baentsch at least were waiting for hours to see whether some trivial changes were OK), and
- we decided yesterday to curtail support for "problematic" algorithms on Windows
can I suggest we reduce Windows/AppVeyor-based checkin testing considerably, e.g., with a blacklist of algorithms we don't want to run --at least on Windows--at every check-in?

Can I ask for your comments on this proposal, @dstebila @xvzcf @christianpaquin ? Anyone else?

comment.body: Just noting that it seems to be the SPHINCS and Rainbow variants that impose a big slow down on the Appveyor tests.
Should we add Windows CI using AppVeyor?
@dstebila That will be great. Can you please add it? I'm not too familiar with Circle.

> @dstebila That will be great. Can you please add it? I'm not too familiar with Circle.

AppVeyor, not Circle, for Windows CI.

@dstebila Done, AppVeyor passes. Any idea why Circle is failing? No changes whatsoever from my side, except an environment variable (now we don't need to specify `LIBOQS_INSTALL_PATH`, but simply add the location of the library to the `PATH`).
Full Windows support + AppVeyor CI integration
